prompt: Write a function called is_palindrome that takes a string as an argument and returns true if and only if that string is a palindrome (is exactly the same forwards and backwards, including capitalization).
Create a variable called {{ var_name }} and set the value of {{ var_name }} to be {{ y }}.
solution: var {{ var_name }} = {{ y }};
test: console.log({{ var_name }});

prompt: Create a function count(word, words) which returns the number of values in the array words which are equal to word using a while loop.

Write a function called sum_every_{{ nth }} that takes a array of integers as an
argument and returns the sum of every {{ nth }} number in the array, starting
with the first number.
Define a function multiply_by_{{ x }}(num) that takes in one number as input and returns the number multiplied by {{ x }}

Write a function called is_capitalized that takes a string as its argument and
returns true if and only if it starts with a capital letter.
Create a function count_odd(nums) which returns the number of odd values in nums using a for loop.

Write a function called is_prime that takes an integer as an argument and
returns true if and only if it is prime.
hint:
Remember that 1 is not a prime number! Otherwise, a number is prime
if its only factors are 1 and itself.
test:
for (var i = 1; i < 1000; i++)
  console.log(is_prime(i));

prompt:
Write a function called contains_{{ x }} that takes a string as an argument and
returns true if and only if the string contains the character '{{ x }}'. Take
capitalization into account.

Create a variable called {{ var_name }} and set the value of {{ var_name }} to be {{ x }}. Create another variable called {{ var_name1 }} and set the value of {{ var_name1 }} to be {{ y }}. Print the sum of {{ var_name }} and {{ var_name1 }} by executing the line "console.log({{ var_name }} + {{ var_name1 }});"
test:
console.log({{ var_name }});
console.log({{ var_name1 }});

prompt: Print out every {{ nth }} character in "{{ str }}" using a while loop.
test: // pass

prompt: Write a function called first_word that takes in a sentence as the argument and returns the first word of the sentence. Then write the following line to test if your function works "console.log(first_word('{{ s1 }}'));".
hint:
Look at this cheatsheet and read about string manipulation (in particular the split method)!
To help you get started, below is a function called double that takes in one argument a and returns a * 2. 
function double(a):
   return a * 2

Make sure you aren't printing anything extra or else we won't be able to validate your answer.
test: console.log(first_word('my pink pony'));

prompt:
Write a function called same_num_{{ x }} that takes two strings as arguments and
returns true if and only if they have exactly the same number of the character
"{{ x }}".

Create a function count_until(value, n, words) which returns the number of values not equal to value in the array words before the nth occurrence of value, using a for loop. The function should return the length of the array words minus the number of times value occurs if value occurs fewer than n times in words.

Write a function called prefix_suffix_{{ n }}(x, y) that takes two strings x, y as arguments and returns true if and only if the first {{ n }} characters of x are exactly the same as the last {{ n }} characters of y.

Write a function called sum_phone_parts that takes a string of a 10-digit phone
number in the form "(xxx) yyy-zzzz" as its argument and returns the sum of its
constituent parts, i.e. xxx+yyy+zzzz. For example,
sum_phone_parts("(234) 567-8901") should return 9702.
test:
for (var x in {{ xs }})
  console.log(sum_phone_parts(x));

prompt:
Write a function called pig_latin that takes a sentence string as its argument
and returns it with each of its words converted to pig latin. This means take
all consonants from the beginning of each word (if there are any) and move them
to the end of the word, and then append "ay" to the word. For example,
pig_latin("A great surprise") should return "Aay eatgray urprisesay".
hint:
Remember to check for upper as well as lower case letters when going through
each word looking for the first block of consonants.
test:
for (var x in {{ xs }})
  console.log(pig_latin(x));

prompt: Create a function called count_multiples_of_{{ x }}(array) that takes in a array of integers and returns the number of elements in the array that are a multiple of {{ x }}. Then verify that your function works by executing "console.log(count_multiples_of_{{ x }}({{ random_list }}));"
Write a function called do_arithmetic that takes arguments x, y, and z and returns (x {{ op0 }} y) {{ op1 }} z.
Write a function called make_sentence that takes an array of strings (words) as an argument and returns the string created by concatenating all the words with spaces in between.

Write a function called capitalize_every_{{ nth }}_letter that takes a string as
its argument and returns a new version of it with every {{ nth }} letter in it
capitalized, starting with the first letter. Any non-letter characters should
remain unchanged and should not be counted when determining every {{ nth }}
letter.

Create a function called count_{{ x }}(array) that takes in an array of integers and returns the number of times {{ x }} appears in the array. Then verify that your function works by executing "console.log(count_{{ x }}({{ random_list }}));"

Write a function called return_n_{{ x }} that takes an integer as its argument
and returns a string that is made up of the word "{{ x }}" repeated that many
times, separated by spaces. For example, return_n_{{ x }}(4) should return
"{{ x }} {{ x }} {{ x }} {{ x }} {{ x }}".
test:
for (var i = 0; i < 20; i++)
  console.log(return_n_{{ x }}(i));

prompt:
Write a function called filter_multiples_of_{{ n }} that takes a array of
integers as an argument and returns a new array with only its numbers that are
multiples of {{ n }}.

Write a function called reverse_sentence_words that takes a sentence string as its argument and returns a new string with every individual word (separated by spaces) reversed, but in the same order as they appeared in the original sentence.
Write a function called reverse_string that takes a string as its argument and returns the same string in reverse.
Create a function called return_word() that takes nothing as arguments and simply returns the word '{{ x }}'.
test: console.log(return_word());

prompt: Create a function called multiply_array(array) that takes in a array of integers and returns the product of the array. Then verify that your function works by executing "console.log(multiply_array({{ random_list }}));".

prompt:
Write a function called longer_than_{{ n }} that takes a string as its argument
and returns true if and only if it has more than {{ n }} characters.

Write a function called is_leap_year(year) that takes in a year as an input and returns true if the year is a leap year and returns false if the year is not a leap year. Remember years that are divisible by 4 are leap years, with the exception that years that are divisible by 100 are not leap years, with the exception that years that are divisible by 400 are leap years. Then test your function by executing "console.log(is_leap_year(2000));", "console.log(is_leap_year(2012));", "console.log(is_leap_year(2013));", "console.log(is_leap_year(2100));".

The syntax to print out the number 5 is 
 console.log(5);
test:

console.log({{ var_name1 }});

prompt:
Write a function called get_time_str that takes an integer number of seconds as
its argument and returns a string in the form "x hours, y minutes, z
seconds", where x, y, and z are integers. For example, get_time_str(5000) should
return "1 hours, 23 minutes, 20 seconds".

Write a function called max_prefix(x, y) that takes two strings x, y as arguments and returns the number of characters that are the same at the beginning of both x and y. For example, max_prefix("hello", "hero") should return 2.

Write a function called print_{{ x }}_return_{{ y }} that prints '{{ x }}' and
then returns '{{ y }}'. Call this function once to see what happens but don't
print the result of calling it.
hint:
Here's a function called print_hello_return_goodbye that prints "hello" and then returns "goodbye": 
function print_hello_return_goodbye() {
  console.log('hello');
  return 'goodbye';
}
Did you remember to call your function to test it at the end of the program? In order to call a function we type its name and then parentheses with its arguments inside (or none if no arguments), for example: 
print_hello_return_goodbye()
test: console.log(print_{{ x }}_return_{{ y }}());

23 minutes, 20 seconds") should return 5000.

Write a function called get_date that takes an integer number of days as its
argument and returns a string that is a date formatted as "month day,
year". Consider day 0 to be January 1, 1970. For example, get_date(3) should
return "January 4, 1970". No need to account for years BCE.
hint:
Leap years are those when the year number is divisible by 4, except for those where the year number is divisible by 100 and not divisible by 400.
Also, remember to account for negative numbers of days!
